text: print.moneca() provides formatted output, can access raw statistics analysis:
code:
# The MONECA object contains all the raw data for 30-class system cat("MONECA object structure overview:
") #> MONECA object structure overview: cat("Class:", class(seg), "
") #> Class: moneca cat("Components:", names(seg), "
") #> Components: segment.list mat.list small.cell.reduction cat("Number of hierarchical levels:", length(seg$segment.list), "
") #> Number of hierarchical levels: 4  # Show detailed structure (limiting depth for readability) str(seg, max.level = 1) #> List of 3 #>  $ segment.list        :List of 4 #>  $ mat.list            :List of 4 #>  $ small.cell.reduction: num 10 #>  - attr(*, "class")= chr "moneca"  # Access and summarize specific components cat("
Detailed component analysis:
") #>  #> Detailed component analysis: cat("Number of matrices:", length(seg$mat.list), "
") #> Number of matrices: 4 for(i in 1:length(seg$mat.list)) {   dims <- dim(seg$mat.list[[i]])   cat("Matrix", i, "dimensions:", dims[1], "x", dims[2], "
") } #> Matrix 1 dimensions: 31 x 31  #> Matrix 2 dimensions: 13 x 13  #> Matrix 3 dimensions: 8 x 8  #> Matrix 4 dimensions: 5 x 5  cat("
Segment memberships by level:
") #>  #> Segment memberships by level: for(i in 1:length(seg$segment.list)) {   if(i == 1) {     n_segments <- length(seg$segment.list[[i]])     cat("Level", i, ": Individual classes (1 to", n_segments, ")
")   } else {     # seg$segment.list[[i]] is a list of segments, each containing class indices     n_segments <- length(seg$segment.list[[i]])     segment_sizes <- sapply(seg$segment.list[[i]], length)     cat("Level", i, ": ", n_segments, "segments with sizes:",          paste(sort(segment_sizes, decreasing = TRUE), collapse = ", "), "
")   } } #> Level 1 : Individual classes (1 to 30 ) #> Level 2 :  10 segments with sizes: 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 2, 2  #> Level 3 :  5 segments with sizes: 6, 5, 5, 4, 4  #> Level 4 :  3 segments with sizes: 10, 8, 7  # Show sample segment memberships for first 15 classes cat("
Sample segment memberships (first 15 classes):
") #>  #> Sample segment memberships (first 15 classes): if(length(seg$segment.list) >= 2) {   # Use segment.membership() function to get proper membership vectors   membership <- segment.membership(seg)      sample_df <- data.frame(     Class = 1:15,     Level_1 = membership[[1]][1:15]   )      if(length(membership) >= 2) {     sample_df$Level_2 <- membership[[2]][1:15]   }      if(length(membership) >= 3) {     sample_df$Level_3 <- membership[[3]][1:15]   }      print(sample_df) } #>    Class  Level_1 Level_2 #> 1      1 Class 01     4.2 #> 2      2 Class 02     4.2 #> 3      3 Class 03     4.2 #> 4      4 Class 04     4.2 #> 5      5 Class 05     4.2 #> 6      6 Class 06     4.2 #> 7      7 Class 07     4.2 #> 8      8 Class 08     4.2 #> 9      9 Class 09     3.5 #> 10    10 Class 10     3.5 #> 11    11 Class 11     3.5 #> 12    12 Class 12     3.5 #> 13    13 Class 13     3.5 #> 14    14 Class 14     4.3 #> 15    15 Class 15     4.3

title: Joint Parameter Calibration in MONECA
text: MONECA algorithm uses two key parameters control filtering process: - small.cell.reduction: Filters raw mobility counts relative risk calculation - cut.: Filters relative risk values calculation vignette demonstrates calibrate parameters jointly achieve optimal clustering results.

previous_headings: Joint Parameter Calibration in MONECA > Mathematical Relationships
title: Joint Parameter Calibration in MONECA
text: parameters work two-stage filtering pipeline: Stage 1: Raw count filtering small.cell.reduction Important: Since mobility counts integers, small.cell.reduction must integer. Non-integer values automatically rounded nearest integer. Stage 2: Relative risk filtering cut.Note: cut.can positive real number since operates continuous relative risk values.
code: if (mobility_count[i,j] < small.cell.reduction)    then mobility_count[i,j] = 0 relative_risk[i,j] = observed[i,j] / expected[i,j] if (relative_risk[i,j] < cut.off)    then relative_risk[i,j] = NA

previous_headings: Joint Parameter Calibration in MONECA > Mathematical Relationships
title: Joint Parameter Calibration in MONECA
text: parameters multiplicative effects network sparsity: P(edge retained)=P(count≥scr)×P(RR≥cutoff|count≥scr)P(\text{edge retained}) = P(\text{count} \geq \text{scr}) \times P(\text{RR} \geq \text{cutoff} | \text{count} \geq \text{scr})

title: Joint Parameter Calibration in MONECA
text: joint calibration framework automatically ensures small.cell.reduction values integers, since parameter filters integer mobility counts. provides several benefits: Mathematical accuracy: Parameters correspond actual filtering behavior Computational efficiency: Eliminates redundant testing equivalent parameter combinations Clearer interpretation: Integer thresholds intuitive count data

text: Get data-driven suggestions parameter ranges: Suggested Parameter Ranges Method
code: # Conservative approach (safer, less aggressive filtering) conservative <- suggest_parameter_ranges(mobility_data, method = "conservative")  # Moderate approach (balanced filtering) moderate <- suggest_parameter_ranges(mobility_data, method = "moderate")   # Aggressive approach (more stringent filtering) aggressive <- suggest_parameter_ranges(mobility_data, method = "aggressive")  # Compare suggestions comparison <- data.frame(   Method = c("Conservative", "Moderate", "Aggressive"),   SCR_Min = c(conservative$scr_range[1], moderate$scr_range[1], aggressive$scr_range[1]),   SCR_Max = c(conservative$scr_range[2], moderate$scr_range[2], aggressive$scr_range[2]),   Cutoff_Min = c(conservative$cutoff_range[1], moderate$cutoff_range[1], aggressive$cutoff_range[1]),   Cutoff_Max = c(conservative$cutoff_range[2], moderate$cutoff_range[2], aggressive$cutoff_range[2]) )  knitr::kable(comparison, digits = 2,               caption = "Suggested Parameter Ranges by Method")

code: # Install development version from GitHub install.packages("devtools") library(devtools) install_github("gmontaletti/moneca")  # Install dependencies install.packages(c("ggplot2", "ggraph", "igraph", "dplyr", "tidygraph",                     "RColorBrewer", "scales", "toOrdinal"))

title: Mobility Network Clustering Analysis with Auto-Tuning
code: library(moneca)  # Generate synthetic mobility data mobility_data <- generate_mobility_data(   n_classes = 6,   n_total = 5000,   immobility_strength = 0.7,   class_clustering = 0.3,   seed = 123 )  # Run MONECA analysis with auto-tuning seg <- moneca(mobility_data, segment.levels = 3,                auto_tune = TRUE, auto_tune_method = "stability") print(seg)  # Modern network visualization plot_moneca_ggraph(seg,                    node_color = "segment",                    title = "Social Mobility Network")  # Ego network analysis plot_ego_ggraph(seg, mobility_data, ego_id = 3)  # Analyze segment membership membership <- segment.membership(seg) print(membership)

title: Mobility Network Clustering Analysis with Auto-Tuning
text: MONECA includes advanced auto-tuning capabilities automatically optimize small.cell.reduction parameter improved clustering quality:
code: # Stability-based auto-tuning (recommended for general use) seg_stable <- moneca(mobility_data, segment.levels = 2,                      auto_tune = TRUE, auto_tune_method = "stability")  # Quality-optimized auto-tuning (best clustering performance)   seg_quality <- moneca(mobility_data, segment.levels = 2,                       auto_tune = TRUE, auto_tune_method = "quality")  # Performance-balanced auto-tuning (speed vs quality trade-off) seg_balanced <- moneca(mobility_data, segment.levels = 2,                        auto_tune = TRUE, auto_tune_method = "performance",                        performance_weight = 0.3)  # Multi-objective Pareto optimization seg_pareto <- moneca(mobility_data, segment.levels = 2,                      auto_tune = TRUE, auto_tune_method = "pareto")  # Cross-validation based tuning (conservative approach) seg_cv <- moneca(mobility_data, segment.levels = 2,                  auto_tune = TRUE, auto_tune_method = "cross_validation")  # View auto-tuning results auto_result <- attr(seg_stable, "auto_tune_result") print(paste("Optimal parameter:", auto_result$best_parameter)) print(paste("Score:", round(auto_result$best_score, 4)))

title: moneca: Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca-package
text: moneca package implements sophisticated hierarchical clustering algorithm detects mobility patterns social networks. identifies segments high internal mobility finding cliques weighted network representations mobility data, creating nested hierarchical structures reveal underlying organization social mobility. Key Features: Network-based clustering using relative risk matrices Hierarchical segmentation multiple nested levels Modern visualization ggraph ggplot2 Synthetic data generation testing demonstrations Quality metrics assessing segmentation performance Multiple visualization types (network, ego, stair plots) Flexible input formats automatic data validation Core Functions: moneca: Main clustering algorithm find.segments: Core segmentation identification weight.matrix: Relative risk matrix calculation segment.membership: Extract cluster memberships Modern Visualization (Recommended): plot_moneca_ggraph: Network visualization ggraph plot_ego_ggraph: Ego network analysis plot_stair_ggraph: Multi-level segmentation plots Legacy Visualization (Backward Compatibility): gg.moneca: Original ggplot2-based visualization moneca.plot: Base R network plotting ego.plot: Legacy ego network plots stair.plot: Legacy stair plots Data Generation: generate_mobility_data: Create synthetic mobility tables generate_example_datasets: Predefined example datasets

text: mx Mobility matrix analysis. small.cell.reduction Small cell reduction parameter test. cut.Edge weight threshold network construction. Default 1. n_bootstrap Number bootstrap samples generate. Default 50. sample_fraction Fraction data use bootstrap sample. Default 0.8. segment.levels Number hierarchical levels clustering. Default 3.

title: Assess Clustering Stability Using Bootstrap Resampling — assess_clustering_stability

title: Assess Clustering Stability Using Bootstrap Resampling — assess_clustering_stability
text: function performs bootstrap resampling : 1. Creating multiple subsamples mobility matrix 2. Running MONECA clustering subsample 3. Extracting clustering signatures (segment memberships) 4. Computing stability metrics based clustering consistency stability score combines multiple measures including: - Consistency segment assignments across bootstrap samples - Stability hierarchical structure - Robustness clique detection

title: Assess Clustering Stability Using Bootstrap Resampling — assess_clustering_stability
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Generate sample data mobility_data <- generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 6, seed = 123)  # Assess stability for different parameters (uses default n_bootstrap = 50) stability_0 <- assess_clustering_stability(mobility_data,                                           small.cell.reduction = 0) stability_5 <- assess_clustering_stability(mobility_data,                                           small.cell.reduction = 5)  cat("Stability with parameter 0:", stability_0, "\n") cat("Stability with parameter 5:", stability_5, "\n")  # For more thorough assessment, increase n_bootstrap stability_thorough <- assess_clustering_stability(mobility_data,                                                   small.cell.reduction = 2,                                                   n_bootstrap = 100) } # }

title: Parallel Assessment of Clustering Stability Using Bootstrap Resampling — assess_clustering_stability_parallel
text: function parallelizes bootstrap sampling process: - Distributes bootstrap samples across available cores - core independently runs moneca_fast assigned samples - Results combined compute overall stability - Falls back sequential processing parallel packages unavailable Performance improvements: - 4 cores: ~3.5x faster sequential - 8 cores: ~6-7x faster sequential - Scales linearly number cores n_bootstrap

title: Joint Auto-Tuning for small.cell.reduction and cut.off Parameters — auto_tune_joint_parameters
text: mx Mobility matrix analyze. Must square numeric matrix. method Character string specifying optimization strategy: "grid" (default): 2D grid search stability assessment "bayesian": Bayesian optimization using Gaussian Process surrogate modeling     Expected Improvement Upper Confidence Bound acquisition functions.     Efficient expensive evaluations, uses Latin Hypercube Sampling     initial design sequential evaluation adaptive point selection.     Recommended evaluation budget limited parameter space large.     Note: Sequential mathematical necessity - new evaluation point     depends GP model updated previous evaluations. "pareto": Multi-objective Pareto frontier optimization "adaptive": Adaptive refinement starting coarse grid scr_range Numeric vector length 2 specifying range small.cell.reduction parameter. Default c(0, NULL) NULL auto-determines upper bound. Ignored scr_values provided. cutoff_range Numeric vector length 2 specifying range cut.parameter. Default c(0.5, 3). Ignored cutoff_values provided. scr_values Numeric vector custom small.cell.reduction values test. provided, overrides scr_range n_grid_points SCR dimension. Values must non-negative converted integers. Allows targeted testing specific parameter values based prior knowledge domain expertise. Default NULL. cutoff_values Numeric vector custom cut.values test. provided, overrides cutoff_range n_grid_points cutoff dimension. Values must positive. Enables focused evaluation specific threshold values identified previous analysis. Default NULL. n_grid_points Integer number grid points per dimension grid search. Default 10. Ignored dimensions custom values. Larger values provide finer resolution increase computation time. n_bootstrap Integer number bootstrap samples stability assessment. Default 50. Higher values improve stability estimation accuracy increase computation time. objectives Character vector optimization objectives. Options include: "stability", "quality", "sparsity", "modularity". Default c("stability", "quality"). Multiple objectives combined using weighted aggregation. weights Numeric vector weights combining multiple objectives. Must sum 1. Default equal weights. Allows prioritization specific clustering properties optimization. seed Integer seed reproducibility. Default NULL. Ensures consistent results across runs set. verbose Logical indicating whether show detailed progress information. Default TRUE. enabled, displays real-time progress tracking ETA estimation, parameter evaluation updates, performance statistics. Progress tracking works seamlessly sequential parallel execution. parallel Character logical indicating parallel processing preference. Can "auto" (default, intelligent switching), TRUE/FALSE (force parallel/sequential), "parallel"/"sequential" explicit control. "auto", function analyzes problem characteristics system resources make optimal decision. Progress tracking maintained across parallel workers. Method-specific behavior: Grid search: Can parallelize across parameter combinations Adaptive: Can parallelize within refinement phase Bayesian: Uses sequential evaluation regardless setting     due mathematical dependencies evaluations. Individual evaluations     may use internal parallelization available. plot_surface Logical indicating whether plot optimization surface. Default FALSE. Creates interactive visualization parameter space optimization results enabled. bayesian_iterations Integer number Bayesian optimization iterations. Default 20. Controls number sequential evaluations initial design points. Higher values allow thorough exploration increase computation time. used method = "bayesian". acquisition_function Character string specifying acquisition function Bayesian optimization. Options : "ei" (default): Expected Improvement - balances exploration exploitation "ucb": Upper Confidence Bound - exploration-focused used method = "bayesian". exploration_factor Numeric exploration parameter acquisition function. Default 0.1. Controls exploration vs exploitation trade-: Smaller values (e.g., 0.01-0.05): exploitation, faster convergence Larger values (e.g., 0.1-0.5): exploration, better global search used method = "bayesian". n_initial Integer number initial design points Bayesian optimization. Default 5. points sampled using Latin Hypercube Sampling provide good coverage parameter space sequential optimization begins. points provide better initialization increase initial cost. used method = "bayesian".

title: Joint Auto-Tuning for small.cell.reduction and cut.off Parameters — auto_tune_joint_parameters
text: list class "moneca_joint_tuning" containing: optimal_scr Optimal small.cell.reduction value optimal_cutoff Optimal cut.value optimization_surface Matrix objective values parameter grid parameter_grid Data frame tested parameter combinations scores Detailed scores parameter combination method Optimization method used objectives Objectives optimized selection_rationale Explanation parameter selection mathematical_relationship Estimated interaction effects computation_time Total optimization time scr_values Vector tested small.cell.reduction values (custom generated) cutoff_values Vector tested cut.values (custom generated) performance_stats Optimization performance statistics including                          parallel processing efficiency, cache utilization,                          progress tracking metrics

title: Joint Auto-Tuning for small.cell.reduction and cut.off Parameters — auto_tune_joint_parameters
text: enhanced function provides comprehensive joint parameter optimization advanced features progress tracking custom parameter grids: Mathematical Framework: function considers sequential filtering relationship parameters: 1. small.cell.reduction filters raw counts: mx[mx < scr] = 0 2. Relative risk calculation: RR = Observed / Expected 3. cut.filters relative risks: RR[RR < cutoff] = NA Network density affected multiplicatively parameters. function models interaction find optimal combinations. Progress Tracking System: Real-time progress monitoring works seamlessly across execution modes: File-based progress tracking ensures visibility parallel processing ETA estimation based completed evaluations current performance Progress updates shown regular intervals (every 5 Performance statistics including cache hit rates evaluation speed Graceful degradation progress tracking encounters issues Custom Grid Vector Support: Flexible parameter specification allows targeted optimization: Custom vectors override ranges grid point specifications Mixed usage: custom values one parameter, range another Automatic integer conversion small.cell.reduction values Input validation ensures parameter feasibility Smart grid sizing based problem characteristics Performance Optimizations: Multiple efficiency enhancements improve user experience: Intelligent caching system reduces redundant computations Smart parameter ordering optimizes evaluation sequence Early termination large parameter spaces beneficial Adaptive parallel processing based problem size resources Memory management prevents cache overflow long sessions Bayesian Optimization Framework: Bayesian method uses advanced machine learning techniques efficient parameter search, particularly beneficial expensive evaluations: Gaussian Process surrogate modeling: Builds probabilistic model     objective function provides predictions uncertainty estimates Latin Hypercube Sampling: Initial design points strategically     placed using space-filling design optimal coverage Acquisition functions: Balance exploration (searching uncertain regions)     vs exploitation (searching near current best points): Expected Improvement (EI): Maximizes expected improvement current best Upper Confidence Bound (UCB): Optimizes upper confidence bound predictions Sequential evaluation: new point chosen maximize     information gain optimal parameter combination Adaptive point selection: Later evaluations focus     promising regions based accumulated knowledge Bayesian Optimization Sequential: Bayesian optimization inherently sequential due mathematical foundation: new evaluation point depends Gaussian Process model fitted     previous evaluations acquisition function requires updated posterior distribution     completed evaluations select next informative point Parallel evaluation select multiple points using outdated     model, reducing efficiency gained adaptive point selection sequential nature makes Bayesian optimization efficient:     typically finds good solutions far fewer total evaluations     grid search, even though evaluations parallelized Method Selection Guidelines: Choose optimization method based problem characteristics: Grid search: Best small parameter spaces (≤100 evaluations),     comprehensive coverage needed, evaluations fast.     Can fully utilize parallel processing faster wall-clock time. Bayesian optimization: Optimal limited evaluation budgets,     expensive function evaluations, large parameter spaces, seeking     global optimum efficiently. Typically requires 15-50 evaluations.     Sequential execution: May appear slower per unit time due lack     parallelization, often faster overall due requiring fewer total evaluations. Adaptive refinement: Good compromise thoroughness     efficiency, recommended moderate-sized problems. Can parallelize within     refinement phase. Pareto optimization: Use multiple competing objectives     need simultaneous consideration Bayesian Optimization Tuning: Parameter selection Bayesian optimization: n_initial: points (8-15) complex landscapes, fewer (3-8)     smooth functions limited budgets bayesian_iterations: Typically 10-30 problems. iterations     allow better convergence increase computational cost acquisition_function: EI balanced search, UCB exploration exploration_factor: 0.01-0.05 exploitation, 0.1-0.5 exploration

title: Joint Auto-Tuning for small.cell.reduction and cut.off Parameters — auto_tune_joint_parameters
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Generate sample data mobility_data <- generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 6, seed = 123)  # Grid search optimization joint_result <- auto_tune_joint_parameters(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "grid",   n_grid_points = 15,   verbose = TRUE,   plot_surface = TRUE )  # Use optimal parameters segments <- moneca(   mobility_data,   small.cell.reduction = joint_result$optimal_scr,   cut.off = joint_result$optimal_cutoff )  # Adaptive refinement for efficiency adaptive_result <- auto_tune_joint_parameters(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "adaptive",   verbose = TRUE )  # Custom parameter vectors for targeted testing # Useful when you have domain knowledge about effective parameter ranges custom_result <- auto_tune_joint_parameters(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "grid",   scr_values = c(0, 1, 2, 5, 10),  # Specific SCR values to test   cutoff_values = c(0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0),  # Specific cutoff values   verbose = TRUE  # Shows progress with ETA estimation )  # Mixed usage - custom SCR values with cutoff range # Demonstrates flexibility: custom vector + automatic range mixed_result <- auto_tune_joint_parameters(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "grid",   scr_values = c(0, 2, 5, 10, 15),  # Custom SCR values   cutoff_range = c(0.8, 2.5),       # Automatic cutoff range   n_grid_points = 8,                # Grid points for cutoff only   verbose = TRUE )  # Progress tracking demonstration # Note: Progress output appears in console during execution large_scale_result <- auto_tune_joint_parameters(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "grid",   n_grid_points = 20,  # Creates 400 combinations   parallel = "auto",   # Smart parallel processing   verbose = TRUE       # Real-time progress with ETA )  # Access enhanced return information print(large_scale_result$performance_stats)  # Optimization efficiency print(large_scale_result$scr_values)         # Actual values tested print(large_scale_result$cutoff_values)      # Actual values tested  # Bayesian optimization for efficient parameter search # Recommended when evaluation budget is limited or parameter space is large bayesian_result <- auto_tune_joint_parameters(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "bayesian",   bayesian_iterations = 15,  # Sequential evaluations after initial design   acquisition_function = "ei", # Expected Improvement (balanced)   exploration_factor = 0.1,   # Moderate exploration   n_initial = 8,              # Initial Latin Hypercube points   verbose = TRUE )  # Bayesian optimization with high exploration for global search # Useful for complex or multimodal parameter landscapes exploratory_result <- auto_tune_joint_parameters(   mx = mobility_data,    method = "bayesian",   bayesian_iterations = 25,   acquisition_function = "ucb", # Upper Confidence Bound (more exploratory)   exploration_factor = 0.3,     # High exploration   n_initial = 10,   verbose = TRUE )  # Efficient Bayesian search with custom parameter ranges # Combines domain knowledge with efficient optimization efficient_bayesian <- auto_tune_joint_parameters(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "bayesian",   scr_range = c(0, 15),          # Custom SCR range based on data characteristics   cutoff_range = c(0.8, 2.5),    # Custom cutoff range   bayesian_iterations = 12,      # Fewer iterations for quick optimization   acquisition_function = "ei",   exploration_factor = 0.05,     # Low exploration for fast convergence   n_initial = 5,                 # Minimal initial points   verbose = TRUE )  # Compare methods: Grid vs Bayesian efficiency # Demonstrates when to use each approach  # For small parameter spaces: Grid search grid_small <- auto_tune_joint_parameters(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "grid",    n_grid_points = 8,  # 64 total evaluations   verbose = TRUE )  # For equivalent evaluation budget: Bayesian optimization bayesian_equivalent <- auto_tune_joint_parameters(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "bayesian",   n_initial = 8,            # Initial design points     bayesian_iterations = 56, # Sequential evaluations (8 + 56 = 64 total)   acquisition_function = "ei",   exploration_factor = 0.1,   verbose = TRUE )  # Access Bayesian-specific results print(bayesian_result$bayesian_info)      # Bayesian optimization details print(bayesian_result$convergence_history) # Objective improvement over iterations } # }

title: Enhanced Automatic Small Cell Reduction Parameter Tuning with Multi-Objective Optimization — auto_tune_small_cell_reduction
text: mx Mobility matrix analyze. Must square numeric matrix representing mobility flows categories. cut.Numeric threshold edge weights network construction. Default 1. method Character string specifying tuning strategy. Options : "quality" (default, RECOMMENDED): Fast clustering quality optimization (10x faster stability) "stability": Bootstrap-based stability assessment (thorough slower) "performance": Balance quality computational efficiency "pareto": Multi-objective optimization Pareto frontier analysis "cross_validation": Cross-validation based parameter selection "bayesian": Bayesian optimization (requires GPfit package) n_trials Integer number trials stability assessment CV folds. Default 5. Increase 10-20 thorough assessment cost speed. candidate_values Numeric vector candidate values test. NULL, values generated automatically using data-driven methods. performance_weight Numeric weight (0-1) performance vs quality trade-. Higher values prioritize speed quality. Default 0.3. min_density Minimum acceptable network density threshold. Default 0.01. max_candidates Maximum number candidate values evaluate computational efficiency. Default 20. seed Integer seed reproducible results bootstrap sampling. Default NULL. verbose Logical indicating whether show progress messages. Default FALSE. use_cache Logical indicating whether use caching repeated computations. Default TRUE. parallel Character logical indicating parallel processing preference. Can "auto" (default, intelligent switching), TRUE/FALSE (force parallel/sequential), "parallel"/"sequential" explicit control. early_stopping Logical indicating whether use early stopping candidate screening. Default TRUE. pareto_objectives Character vector objectives Pareto optimization. Default c("quality", "performance"). cv_folds Integer number cross-validation folds. Default 5. bayesian_iterations Integer number Bayesian optimization iterations. Default 20.

title: Enhanced Automatic Small Cell Reduction Parameter Tuning with Multi-Objective Optimization — auto_tune_small_cell_reduction
text: list containing: optimal_value Recommended small.cell.reduction parameter value stability_scores Stability assessment results candidate quality_metrics Clustering quality metrics candidate performance_metrics Computational performance metrics candidates_tested Vector candidate values evaluated tuning_method Method used parameter selection selection_rationale Text explanation parameter selection network_properties Network density connectivity metrics computation_time Total time spent parameter tuning

title: Enhanced Automatic Small Cell Reduction Parameter Tuning with Multi-Objective Optimization — auto_tune_small_cell_reduction
text: function implements three tuning strategies: Stability Method: Uses bootstrap resampling assess clustering consistency across data subsamples. Parameters produce stable clustering structures preferred. Quality Method: Optimizes clustering quality using multiple metrics including silhouette coefficients, network modularity, information-theoretic measures. Performance Method: Balances clustering quality computational efficiency, considering analysis time memory requirements. Candidate values automatically generated using percentile-based thresholds, matrix sparsity analysis, network density targets unless explicitly provided.

title: Enhanced Automatic Small Cell Reduction Parameter Tuning with Multi-Objective Optimization — auto_tune_small_cell_reduction
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Generate sample mobility data mobility_data <- generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 6, seed = 123)  # Quality-based tuning (default, fast and recommended) tuning_result <- auto_tune_small_cell_reduction(   mx = mobility_data,   verbose = TRUE )  # Use optimal parameter in moneca analysis segments <- moneca(mobility_data,                   small.cell.reduction = tuning_result$optimal_value)  # Stability-based tuning (slower but more thorough) stability_result <- auto_tune_small_cell_reduction(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "stability",   n_trials = 10,   verbose = TRUE )  # Quality-based tuning with custom candidates custom_result <- auto_tune_small_cell_reduction(   mx = mobility_data,   candidate_values = c(0, 1, 2, 5, 10, 20),   verbose = TRUE )  # Performance-aware tuning performance_result <- auto_tune_small_cell_reduction(   mx = mobility_data,   method = "performance",   performance_weight = 0.5,  # Equal weight to speed and quality   verbose = TRUE ) } # }

title: Comprehensive Cut-off Sensitivity Analysis — cutoff_sensitivity_analysis
code: # Generate synthetic mobility data data <- generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 4, seed = 123)  # Run sensitivity analysis sensitivity <- cutoff_sensitivity_analysis(data, n_points = 20, verbose = FALSE)  # View results head(sensitivity) #> Cut-off Sensitivity Analysis #> ============================ #> Cut-off range: 0.26 to 0.63  #> Number of points evaluated: 6  #>  #> Key metrics across cut-off range: #>  cutoff n_edges mean_strength strength_ratio modularity #>   0.261       5          3.04          0.736   1.67e-16 #>   0.335       5          3.04          0.736   1.67e-16 #>   0.408       5          3.04          0.736   1.67e-16 #>   0.482       5          3.04          0.736   1.67e-16 #>   0.555       5          3.04          0.736   1.67e-16 #>   0.629       5          3.04          0.736   1.67e-16  # Plot key metrics (requires ggplot2) if (require(ggplot2, quietly = TRUE)) {   library(ggplot2)   plot(sensitivity$cutoff, sensitivity$n_edges, type = "l",         xlab = "Cut-off", ylab = "Number of Edges") }

title: Detect System Resources and Capabilities — detect_system_resources
text: function performs comprehensive system analysis: - Detects CPU cores recommends usage (typically total cores - 1) - Estimates available memory large dataset considerations - Checks required packages (foreach, doParallel) - Determines optimal parallel backend (fork vs socket) - Sets platform-specific recommendations

title: Diagnose Parallel Execution — diagnose_parallel_execution
text: Tests whether parallel processing actually using multiple CPU cores running known computation sequentially parallel, monitoring system resources execution, verifying parallel workers active functioning.

title: Diagnose Parallel Execution — diagnose_parallel_execution
code: diagnose_parallel_execution(   n_workers = NULL,   test_duration_sec = 10,   include_cpu_monitoring = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Diagnose Parallel Execution — diagnose_parallel_execution
text: n_workers Number parallel workers test (default: auto-detect). test_duration_sec Duration test computation seconds (default: 10). include_cpu_monitoring Whether monitor CPU usage test. verbose Whether display detailed diagnostic information.

title: Diagnose Parallel Execution — diagnose_parallel_execution
text: List containing diagnostic results: parallel_active Whether parallel processing actually running workers_detected Number active workers detected cpu_usage_parallel CPU usage parallel execution (monitored) cpu_usage_sequential CPU usage sequential execution (monitored) timing_parallel Time taken parallel execution timing_sequential Time taken sequential execution speedup_achieved Actual speedup ratio (sequential/parallel) system_info System resource information diagnostic_summary Human-readable summary results recommendations Actionable recommendations based results

title: Diagnose Parallel Execution — diagnose_parallel_execution
text: function performs several diagnostic tests: 1. **Worker Detection**: Verifies specified number workers created 2. **Computation Test**: Runs identical computations sequentially parallel 3. **CPU Monitoring**: Tracks CPU utilization execution (enabled) 4. **Timing Comparison**: Measures actual execution times calculates speedup 5. **Resource Verification**: Ensures system resources properly utilized test computation involves CPU-intensive matrix operations can benefit parallelization, similar MONECA's weight matrix computations.

title: Diagnose Parallel Execution — diagnose_parallel_execution
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic diagnostic test results <- diagnose_parallel_execution(verbose = TRUE) print(results$diagnostic_summary)  # Test specific number of workers results <- diagnose_parallel_execution(n_workers = 4, verbose = TRUE)  # Include CPU monitoring results <- diagnose_parallel_execution(include_cpu_monitoring = TRUE) } # }

title: Legacy Ego Network Visualization — ego.plot
code: ego.plot(   segments,   mxa.b,   id = 1,   lay = NULL,   edge.size = 0.8,   border.padding = 1,   title.line = TRUE,   vertex.size = "totals",   small.cell.reduction = 5,   edge.weight = "discrete",   color.scheme = "RdPu",   ... )

title: Legacy Ego Network Visualization — ego.plot
text: segments moneca object returned moneca. mxa.b original mobility matrix used moneca analysis. id Integer character specifying focal node (ego) analysis. lay Layout matrix node positioning, typically layout.matrix. edge.size Numeric value edge thickness. Default 0.8. border.padding Numeric value segment boundary padding. Default 1. title.line Logical indicating whether add title line. Default TRUE. vertex.size Specification vertex sizes. "totals", sizes derived row/column totals mobility matrix. Otherwise, uses specified values. small.cell.reduction Numeric threshold vertices receive different shapes indicate low mobility volumes. Default 5. edge.weight Character string specifying edge weight display. "discrete" creates categorical edge weights, otherwise uses continuous weights. color.scheme Character string specifying RColorBrewer color scheme visualization. Default "RdPu". ... Additional arguments passed gg.moneca.

title: Legacy Ego Network Visualization — ego.plot
text: ggplot2 object showing ego network.

title: Legacy Ego Network Visualization — ego.plot
text: function creates focused view mobility patterns single position social structure. highlights incoming outgoing mobility flows uses different visual elements represent: Edge colors/weights relative risk levels Node sizes total mobility volumes Node shapes positions low mobility Node colors mobility share proportions Note: function maintained backward compatibility. new analyses, consider using plot_ego_ggraph offers better performance modern styling options.

title: Find Optimal Cut-off Based on Strength Patterns — find_optimal_cutoff
code: find_optimal_cutoff(   mx,   criterion = "elbow",   cutoff_range = NULL,   n_bootstrap = 30,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Find Optimal Cut-off Based on Strength Patterns — find_optimal_cutoff
text: mx Mobility matrix marginals (last row column contain totals) criterion Optimization criterion use. One : "elbow" Finds "elbow" point strength ratio curve     using point maximum curvature. identifies adding     edges provides diminishing returns network strength concentration.     Best : Automatic, data-driven cutoff selection without     prior assumptions. Good : Finding natural break point     network density strong ties separated weak ties.     Trade-: May optimize specific network properties     like modularity stability. "stability" Evaluates clustering stability using bootstrap     resampling mobility matrix. Finds cutoff segment     assignments consistent across resampled data, measured     coefficient variation node strengths. Best : Ensuring     robust, reproducible clustering results. Good : Applications     stability reliability important optimizing     metrics. Trade-: Computationally expensive (uses n_bootstrap     samples, default 30) may favor connected networks. "balance" Balances edge retention strength concentration     maximizing product: $$score = edge\_retention \times strength\_ratio$$     creates trade-preserving network structure (many edges)     focusing strong ties (high strength ratio). Best :     General-purpose clustering want neither sparse dense     networks. Good : Preserving interpretable network structure     maintaining focus meaningful connections. Trade-:     May produce intermediate solutions excel single metric. "modularity" Maximizes network modularity using fast greedy     community detection. Modularity measures well network separates     distinct communities. Higher modularity indicates stronger within-group     connections weaker -group connections. Best :     Identifying well-defined, non-overlapping social groups mobility classes.     Good : Sociological research focused community structure     social stratification. Trade-: May favor sparser networks     can produce resolution limit issues large networks. "information" Minimizes information loss reducing network     complexity maximizing: $$efficiency = strength\_retention / edge\_retention$$     criterion keeps important connections (high strength)     maximally simplifying network (edges). Best : Creating     parsimonious network representations maximum explanatory power.     Good : Visualization interpretation network clarity     important. Trade-: May produce sparse networks     lose nuanced structural information. cutoff_range Numeric vector cut-values test. NULL (default), automatically determined relative risk distribution (5th 95th percentile range) n_bootstrap Integer. Number bootstrap samples stability criterion. Higher values provide reliable stability estimates increase computation time. Default 30, provides reasonable balance accuracy speed verbose Logical. Whether show progress messages sensitivity analysis details. Default TRUE

title: Find Optimal Cut-off Based on Strength Patterns — find_optimal_cutoff
text: list class "optimal_cutoff" containing: optimal_cutoff Numeric. recommended cut-value based       specified criterion criterion Character. criterion used optimization metrics Data frame row. Network metrics optimal cut-,       including n_edges, mean_strength, strength_ratio, modularity, n_components,       clustering_coefficient sensitivity_analysis Data frame. Complete sensitivity analysis       across tested cut-values, useful plotting analysis explanation Character. Human-readable explanation       cut-selected, including key metric values

title: Find Optimal Cut-off Based on Strength Patterns — find_optimal_cutoff
text: cut-parameter central MONECA clustering determines   relative risk values create edges mobility network. Higher   cut-offs produce sparser networks focusing strongest mobility ties,   lower cut-offs include weaker connections produce denser networks. Choosing appropriate cut-affects: Network density interpretability Number size detected clusters Stability cluster assignments Balance within-cluster -cluster mobility

title: Find Optimal Cut-off Based on Strength Patterns — find_optimal_cutoff
text: Start criterion = "elbow" automatic, data-driven       baseline cut-Run sensitivity analysis visualize different cut-offs affect       network properties stability critical (e.g., longitudinal comparisons),       use criterion = "stability" identifying distinct communities goal, use       criterion = "modularity" Compare results multiple criteria assess robustness Visualize resulting networks using plot_cutoff_analysis()       plot_moneca_ggraph()

title: Find Optimal Cut-off Based on Strength Patterns — find_optimal_cutoff
text: Fast criteria: "elbow", "balance", "modularity", "information"       (seconds typical datasets) Slow criteria: "stability" (minutes n_bootstrap=30,       scales linearly n_bootstrap quadratically matrix size) large matrices (>50 classes), consider reducing n_bootstrap       using coarser cutoff_range criteria benefit narrower cutoff_range prior       knowledge appropriate values

title: Find Optimal Cut-off Based on Strength Patterns — find_optimal_cutoff
code:
# Generate synthetic mobility data data <- generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 5, seed = 123)  # 1. Find optimal cut-off using different criteria optimal_elbow <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = "elbow", verbose = FALSE) optimal_balance <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = "balance", verbose = FALSE) optimal_mod <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = "modularity", verbose = FALSE)  # Compare results print(optimal_elbow) #> Optimal Cut-off Analysis #> ======================== #> Optimal cut-off value: 1.382  #> Criterion used: elbow  #> Explanation: Elbow point: Retains 44.4% of edges while maintaining 71.7% strength concentration  #>  #> Metrics at optimal point: #>   n_edges: 4.000 #>   mean_strength: 2.962 #>   strength_ratio: 0.717 #>   modularity: 0.221 #>   n_components: 1.000 print(optimal_balance) #> Optimal Cut-off Analysis #> ======================== #> Optimal cut-off value: 0.219  #> Criterion used: balance  #> Explanation: Balanced trade-off: 100.0% edges, 71.9% strength ratio, modularity = 0.073  #>  #> Metrics at optimal point: #>   n_edges: 9.000 #>   mean_strength: 4.324 #>   strength_ratio: 0.719 #>   modularity: 0.073 #>   n_components: 1.000 print(optimal_mod) #> Optimal Cut-off Analysis #> ======================== #> Optimal cut-off value: 1.200  #> Criterion used: modularity  #> Explanation: Maximum modularity (0.221): 4 edges, 1 components  #>  #> Metrics at optimal point: #>   n_edges: 4.000 #>   mean_strength: 2.962 #>   strength_ratio: 0.717 #>   modularity: 0.221 #>   n_components: 1.000  # Extract just the cut-off values for comparison cat("Elbow method suggests:", round(optimal_elbow$optimal_cutoff, 3), "
") #> Elbow method suggests: 1.382  cat("Balance method suggests:", round(optimal_balance$optimal_cutoff, 3), "
") #> Balance method suggests: 0.219  cat("Modularity method suggests:", round(optimal_mod$optimal_cutoff, 3), "
") #> Modularity method suggests: 1.2   # 2. Visualize sensitivity curves to understand criterion choices sensitivity <- optimal_elbow$sensitivity_analysis  if (require(ggplot2, quietly = TRUE)) {   library(ggplot2)    # Plot strength ratio (elbow criterion looks for inflection point here)   p1 <- ggplot(sensitivity, aes(x = cutoff, y = strength_ratio)) +     geom_line() +     geom_vline(xintercept = optimal_elbow$optimal_cutoff,                linetype = "dashed", color = "red") +     labs(title = "Elbow Point in Strength Ratio",          x = "Cut-off", y = "Strength Ratio") +     theme_minimal()   print(p1)    # Plot modularity (modularity criterion maximizes this)   p2 <- ggplot(sensitivity, aes(x = cutoff, y = modularity)) +     geom_line() +     geom_vline(xintercept = optimal_mod$optimal_cutoff,                linetype = "dashed", color = "blue") +     labs(title = "Modularity Across Cut-offs",          x = "Cut-off", y = "Modularity") +     theme_minimal()   print(p2) }    # 3. Practical workflow: Find optimal cut-off and run MONECA optimal <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = "balance", verbose = FALSE)  # Use the optimal cut-off in MONECA clustering seg <- moneca(data, cut.off = optimal$optimal_cutoff, segment.levels = 3) #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |=========                                                             |  12%   |                                                                               |==================                                                    |  25% #> 33% ready! #>    |                                                                               |==========================                                            |  38%   |                                                                               |===================================                                   |  50% #> 56% ready! #>    |                                                                               |============================================                          |  62%   |                                                                               |====================================================                  |  75% #> 78% ready! #>    |                                                                               |=============================================================         |  88%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% #> 100% ready! #>  #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0% #> 100% ready! #>   # Visualize the resulting network if (require(ggraph, quietly = TRUE)) {   plot_moneca_ggraph(seg, level = 1, node_color = "segment") }   # 4. Compare network properties across criteria criteria <- c("elbow", "balance", "modularity", "information") results <- lapply(criteria, function(crit) {   opt <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = crit, verbose = FALSE)   data.frame(     criterion = crit,     cutoff = opt$optimal_cutoff,     n_edges = opt$metrics$n_edges,     modularity = opt$metrics$modularity,     n_components = opt$metrics$n_components   ) }) comparison <- do.call(rbind, results) print(comparison) #>     criterion    cutoff n_edges modularity n_components #> 1       elbow 1.3816297       4 0.22056911            1 #> 2     balance 0.2191032       9 0.07286871            1 #> 3  modularity 1.1999850       4 0.22056911            1 #> 4 information 1.8902351       2 0.00000000            3  # 5. Stability analysis (more computationally intensive) # \donttest{ optimal_stable <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = "stability",                                       n_bootstrap = 50, verbose = TRUE) #> Running sensitivity analysis... #> Analyzing RR distribution to determine cut-off range... #> Cut-off range: 0.22 to 2.00 #>    | title: Generate Realistic Synthetic Mobility Data — generate_mobility_data
code: generate_mobility_data(   n_classes = 10,   n_total = 10000,   immobility_strength = 0.6,   class_clustering = 0.3,   noise_level = 0.1,   class_names = NULL,   seed = NULL )

title: Generate Realistic Synthetic Mobility Data — generate_mobility_data
text: n_classes Integer specifying number social classes occupational categories. Must least 2. Default 10. n_total Integer specifying total sample size (number individuals). Must least large n_classes. Default 10000. immobility_strength Numeric value (0-1) controlling strength diagonal immobility (tendency remain origin class). Higher values create rigid class structures. Default 0.6. class_clustering Numeric value (0-1) controlling tendency mobility adjacent classes social hierarchy. Higher values create gradual, short-distance mobility. Default 0.3. noise_level Numeric value (0-1) controlling amount random mobility non-adjacent classes. Higher values create chaotic mobility patterns. Default 0.1. class_names Character vector names social classes. NULL, classes named "Class 1", "Class 2", etc. Length must equal n_classes. seed Integer random seed ensure reproducible results. Default NULL (seed set).

title: Generate Realistic Synthetic Mobility Data — generate_mobility_data
text: square matrix moneca format : Core matrix Upper-left (n_classes x n_classes) contains mobility flows Row margins Last column contains origin class totals Column margins Last row contains destination class totals Grand total Bottom-right cell contains total sample size matrix includes row column names easy interpretation.

title: Generate Realistic Synthetic Mobility Data — generate_mobility_data
text: function generates mobility data using hierarchical model reflects common patterns social mobility research: Diagonal Dominance: people remain origin class Distance Effects: Mobility likely adjacent classes Marginal Heterogeneity: Class sizes vary realistically Random Component: unpredictable mobility occurs generated data can used test different mobility regimes affect moneca segmentation create realistic examples demonstrations. Parameter combinations: High immobility + low clustering = rigid class boundaries Low immobility + high clustering = fluid structured mobility High noise = chaotic mobility patterns Balanced parameters = realistic social mobility

title: Generate Realistic Synthetic Mobility Data — generate_mobility_data
code: # Basic synthetic data with default parameters basic_data <- generate_mobility_data() print(basic_data[1:6, 1:6])  # Show first 5 classes plus totals #>         Class 1 Class 2 Class 3 Class 4 Class 5 Class 6 #> Class 1     790     219     103      16       9      16 #> Class 2     207     737     195     104      14      10 #> Class 3      40      76     253      68      44       4 #> Class 4       2      24      56     229      64      30 #> Class 5      22      22     193     341    1335     343 #> Class 6       9       6      13      70     151     563  # Small example for quick testing test_data <- generate_mobility_data(   n_classes = 5,   n_total = 1000,   immobility_strength = 0.7,   class_clustering = 0.2,   seed = 42 )  # Professional class structure with custom names professional_data <- generate_mobility_data(   n_classes = 6,   n_total = 5000,   class_names = c("Upper", "Upper-Middle", "Middle",                    "Lower-Middle", "Working", "Lower"),   immobility_strength = 0.5,   class_clustering = 0.4,   seed = 123 )  # Highly fluid mobility regime fluid_data <- generate_mobility_data(   n_classes = 8,   immobility_strength = 0.3,   class_clustering = 0.1,   noise_level = 0.3 )  # Use in moneca analysis seg <- moneca(test_data, segment.levels = 3) #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0% #> 33% ready! #>    |                                                                               |===================================                                   |  50% #> 67% ready! #>    |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% #> 100% ready! #>  plot_moneca_ggraph(seg, title = "Synthetic Mobility Analysis")

what: MONECA - Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca
title: MONECA - Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca
text: Main function performing hierarchical clustering analysis mobility tables. MONECA creates weighted networks mobility data uses cliques identify discrete nested clusters positions high internal mobility.

title: MONECA - Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca
code: moneca(   mx = mx,   segment.levels = 3,   cut.off = 1,   mode = "symmetric",   delete.upper.tri = TRUE,   small.cell.reduction = 0,   auto_tune = FALSE,   tune_method = "stability",   tune_verbose = FALSE,   use_maximal_cliques = FALSE )

title: MONECA - Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca
text: mx mobility table (square matrix) row column totals last row/column. Row names identify categories/classes. segment.levels Integer specifying number hierarchical segmentation levels compute. Default 3. algorithm may return fewer levels meaningful segmentation possible. cut.Numeric threshold minimum relative risk considered significant tie. Default 1 (mobility random expectation required). mode Character string specifying edge mode ("symmetric", "Mutual", "Unmutual"). Currently fully implemented - uses symmetric mode. delete.upper.tri Logical indicating whether use lower triangle efficiency. Default TRUE. small.cell.reduction Numeric value handle small cell counts. Cells counts threshold set 0. Default 0 (reduction). auto_tune Logical indicating whether automatically tune small.cell.reduction parameter. TRUE, uses optimization methods select best value. Default FALSE. tune_method Character string specifying auto-tuning method auto_tune TRUE. Options "stability" (default), "quality", "performance". See auto_tune_small_cell_reduction details. tune_verbose Logical indicating whether print verbose messages auto-tuning. Default FALSE. use_maximal_cliques Logical indicating whether use maximal cliques (faster, fewer cliques) instead cliques (slower, complete enumeration). Default FALSE (use cliques algorithmic correctness). Set TRUE performance optimization dense graphs.

title: MONECA - Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca
text: object class "moneca" containing: segment.list list segment memberships hierarchical level.       element list vectors containing original row indices. mat.list list aggregated mobility matrices level,       rows/columns represent segments instead original categories. small.cell.reduction small cell reduction parameter used.

title: MONECA - Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca
text: original antongrau/MONECA implementation progress bar functionality. memory-optimized version, use moneca_fast(). MONECA implements iterative algorithm : Converts mobility table relative risk matrix Identifies network cliques based threshold Groups nodes segments using clique structure Aggregates mobility table segments Repeats process specified number levels algorithm stops early segmentation possible (e.g., nodes collapse single segment).

title: MONECA - Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca

title: MONECA Fast - Memory-Optimized Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca_fast
text: version includes intelligent memory management dense graphs optimized clique enumeration prevent memory issues large datasets. MONECA implements iterative algorithm : Converts mobility table relative risk matrix Identifies network cliques based threshold Groups nodes segments using clique structure Aggregates mobility table segments Repeats process specified number levels algorithm stops early segmentation possible (e.g., nodes collapse single segment). **Algorithm Features:** Simple memory-efficient clique testing using direct subset checking Intelligent dense graph detection fallback maximal cliques Streamlined implementation based original bejler.test approach Maintains algorithmic correctness minimizing memory overhead implementation optimized single-core performance using: Vectorized matrix operations improved speed Optional sparse matrix support via use.sparse parameter Early stopping via min.density threshold (disabled default) Clique size limiting via max.clique.size parameter Produces identical results moneca moneca_parallel using default parameters. use: Single-core systems laptops Small medium datasets (< 50 classes) want explicit control optimization parameters multi-core systems large datasets (> 50 classes), consider using moneca_parallel instead better performance parallelization.

title: Parallel moneca - High-Performance Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca_parallel
text: mx mobility table (square matrix) row column totals last row/column. Row names identify categories/classes. segment.levels Integer specifying number hierarchical segmentation levels compute. Default 3. cut.Numeric threshold minimum relative risk considered significant tie. Default 1. mode Character string specifying edge mode ("symmetric", "Mutual", "Unmutual"). Default "symmetric". delete.upper.tri Logical indicating whether use lower triangle efficiency. Default TRUE. small.cell.reduction Numeric value handle small cell counts. Cells counts threshold set 0. Default 0. n.cores Integer specifying number CPU cores use. Default NULL (auto-detect optimal number). parallel.backend Character string specifying parallel backend: "auto" (default), "fork" (Unix/Mac ), "socket" (platforms). chunk.size Integer specifying chunk size parallel processing. Default NULL (auto-calculate based data size). fallback.sequential Logical indicating whether fall back sequential processing parallel fails. Default TRUE. progress Logical indicating whether show progress bars. Default TRUE. auto_tune Logical indicating whether automatically tune small.cell.reduction parameter. TRUE, uses optimization methods select best value. Default FALSE. tune_method Character string specifying auto-tuning method auto_tune TRUE. Options "stability" (default), "quality", "performance". See auto_tune_small_cell_reduction details. tune_verbose Logical indicating whether print verbose messages auto-tuning. Default FALSE. use_maximal_cliques Logical indicating whether use maximal cliques (faster, fewer cliques) instead cliques (slower, complete enumeration). Default FALSE (use cliques algorithmic correctness). Set TRUE performance optimization dense graphs.

title: Parallel moneca - High-Performance Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca_parallel
text: parallel implementation uses several strategies improve performance: Parallel clique detection find.segments Vectorized parallel matrix operations weight.matrix Parallel aggregation segment.matrix Automatic load balancing chunk size optimization Intelligent fallback sequential processing beneficial Produces identical results moneca moneca_fast using default parameters. use: Multi-core systems (desktops, servers, HPC clusters) Large datasets (> 50 classes) computational time critical Performance note: single-core systems small-medium datasets (< 50 classes), consider using moneca_fast instead, may faster due lower parallelization overhead.

title: Temporal Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca_temporal
text: matrix_list List mobility matrices, one time period. matrix must square identical dimensions row/column names. window_size Integer specifying number time periods include moving window. Default 3. segment.levels Integer specifying maximum number hierarchical segmentation levels. Default 3. stability_method Character string specifying method matching segments across time periods: "hungarian" (default): Uses Hungarian algorithm optimal bipartite matching "jaccard": Uses Jaccard similarity segment memberships "overlap": Simple overlap coefficient aggregation_method Character string specifying combine matrices within window: "mean" (default): Average matrices window "sum": Sum matrices "weighted": Weighted average recent periods higher weight cut.Numeric threshold minimum relative risk. Default 1. small.cell.reduction Numeric value handling small cells. Default 0. min_overlap Minimum proportion nodes must overlap segments matching. Default 0.5. parallel Logical indicating whether use parallel processing windows. TRUE, windows processed parallel using multiple CPU cores, can significantly speed analysis large datasets. Uses mclapply Unix/Mac parLapply Windows. Default FALSE. verbose Logical indicating whether show progress messages. Default TRUE. ... Additional arguments passed moneca().

title: Temporal Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca_temporal
text: object class "moneca_temporal" containing: windows List time windows analyzed (start end periods) segment_maps List segment membership matrices window stable_labels Consistently labeled segments across time periods transition_matrix Matrix showing segment--segment transitions moneca_results List full moneca objects window matching_history Details segment matching windows parameters List analysis parameters used

title: Temporal Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca_temporal
text: function performs following steps: 1. Creates overlapping windows specified size input matrices 2. Aggregates matrices within window according aggregation_method 3. Runs moneca clustering aggregated window 4. Matches segments consecutive windows maintain label stability 5. Tracks transitions changes segment composition Segment matching uses either Hungarian algorithm optimal assignment based membership overlap, Jaccard similarity simpler matching. function ensures segment labels remain consistent possible across time periods, making easier track segment evolution.

title: Temporal Mobility Network Clustering Analysis — moneca_temporal
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Generate synthetic monthly mobility data months_data <- lapply(1:12, function(m) {   generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 6, seed = m * 100) })  # Run temporal analysis with 3-month moving window (sequential) temporal_result <- moneca_temporal(   matrix_list = months_data,   window_size = 3,   segment.levels = 3,   stability_method = "hungarian",   verbose = TRUE )  # Run with parallel processing for faster execution temporal_result_parallel <- moneca_temporal(   matrix_list = months_data,   window_size = 3,   segment.levels = 3,   stability_method = "hungarian",   parallel = TRUE,  # Enable parallel processing   verbose = TRUE )  # Print summary print(temporal_result)  # Analyze stability stability <- temporal_stability_analysis(temporal_result) } # }

text: mx Mobility matrix analyze. Must square numeric matrix. scr_range Numeric vector length 2 specifying range small.cell.reduction parameter. Default c(0, NULL) NULL auto-determines upper bound. Ignored scr_values provided. cutoff_range Numeric vector length 2 specifying range cut.parameter. Default c(0.5, 3). Ignored cutoff_values provided. scr_values Numeric vector custom small.cell.reduction values test. provided, overrides scr_range n_grid_points SCR dimension. Default NULL. cutoff_values Numeric vector custom cut.values test. provided, overrides cutoff_range n_grid_points cutoff dimension. Values must positive. Enables focused evaluation specific threshold values identified previous analysis. Default NULL. objectives Character vector optimization objectives. Multiple objectives combined using weighted aggregation. weights Numeric vector weights combining multiple objectives. Must sum 1. Default equal weights. Allows prioritization specific clustering properties optimization. verbose Logical indicating whether show detailed progress information. Default TRUE. enabled, displays real-time progress tracking ETA estimation, parameter evaluation updates, performance statistics. Progress tracking works seamlessly sequential parallel execution. parallel Character logical indicating parallel processing preference. Can "auto" (default, intelligent switching), TRUE/FALSE (force parallel/sequential), "parallel"/"sequential" explicit control. "auto", function analyzes problem characteristics system resources make optimal decision. Progress tracking maintained across parallel workers. title: Ego Network Visualization with ggraph — plot_ego_ggraph
code: # Generate synthetic data and run MONECA mobility_data <- generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 6, seed = 123) seg <- moneca(mobility_data, segment.levels = 3) #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |==========                                                            |  14% #> 25% ready! #>    |                                                                               |====================                                                  |  29%   |                                                                               |==============================                                        |  43% #> 50% ready! #>    |                                                                               |========================================                              |  57%   |                                                                               |==================================================                    |  71% #> 75% ready! #>    |                                                                               |============================================================          |  86%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% #> 100% ready! #>   # Ego network for the middle category (index 3) plot_ego_ggraph(seg, mobility_data, ego_id = 3,                  title = "Mobility from Middle Class")   # Ego network using category name (if available) if (!is.null(rownames(mobility_data))) {   plot_ego_ggraph(seg, mobility_data, ego_id = rownames(mobility_data)[1]) }   # Focus on strong mobility flows only (weight >= 10) plot_ego_ggraph(seg, mobility_data,                  ego_id = 2,                 min_weight = 10,                 title = "Strong Mobility Flows")   # Customized ego plot plot_ego_ggraph(seg, mobility_data,                  ego_id = 2,                 layout = "fr",                 highlight_color = "orange",                 flow_color = "plasma",                 edge_width_range = c(1, 5),                 title = "Professional Class Mobility")   # Ego plot with custom segment labels job_labels <- data.frame(   name = rownames(mobility_data)[-nrow(mobility_data)],   segment_label = c("CEO", "Director", "Manager",                      "Analyst", "Coordinator", "Assistant")[1:length(rownames(mobility_data)[-nrow(mobility_data)])],   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  plot_ego_ggraph(seg, mobility_data,                  ego_id = 1,                 segment_naming = job_labels,                 title = "CEO Mobility Network with Job Titles")

title: Plot MONECA Results as Dendrogram — plot_moneca_dendrogram
text: ggplot2 object representing dendrogram.

title: Plot MONECA Results as Dendrogram — plot_moneca_dendrogram
text: function creates dendrogram visualization clearly shows: individual categories (leaves) grouped level hierarchical relationships segments progressive aggregation individual categories larger segments dendrogram branches show merging points categories segments combined based MONECA algorithm's clique detection. Unlike traditional hierarchical clustering, MONECA can create non-binary trees multiple categories merge simultaneously. Visual Features: Curved branches: Uses smooth curves instead angular segments better aesthetics Horizontal layout: Levels progress horizontally (left right) categories arranged vertically -Crossing Layout: Categories automatically ordered using hierarchical algorithm completely eliminates line crossings levels algorithm processes segments aggregated level , ensuring level, categories grouped optimally prevent crossing lines. creates clearest possible visualization hierarchical structure.

title: Plot MONECA Results as Dendrogram — plot_moneca_dendrogram
code: # Generate synthetic data and run MONECA mobility_data <- generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 8, seed = 123) seg <- moneca(mobility_data, segment.levels = 3) #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |=======                                                               |  10%   |                                                                               |==============                                                        |  20% #> 27% ready! #>    |                                                                               |===============================================================       |  90%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% #> 100% ready! #>  #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0% #> 100% ready! #>   # Basic dendrogram plot_moneca_dendrogram(seg) #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the moneca package. #>   Please report the issue to the authors.   # Dendrogram with mobility-based heights plot_moneca_dendrogram(seg, height_method = "mobility",                        title = "Mobility-based Hierarchical Clustering")   # Horizontal dendrogram without colors plot_moneca_dendrogram(seg, vertical = FALSE, color_segments = FALSE)   # Customize appearance plot_moneca_dendrogram(seg,                        color_palette = "Dark2",                       branch_width = 1.5,                       label_size = 4,                       theme_style = "classic")

text: segments moneca object returned moneca. level Integer vector specifying hierarchical levels visualize. Default displays levels except first (represents individual categories). layout Character string matrix specifying layout algorithm: "fr" (default): Fruchterman-Reingold force-directed layout "kk": Kamada-Kawai layout "dh": Davidson-Harel layout "mds": Multidimensional scaling "stress": Stress majorization Matrix: Custom coordinate matrix (n_nodes x 2) edges Edge matrix "auto" automatically generate using segment.edges. Default "auto". node_size Aesthetic mapping node size: "total": Size total mobility volume (default) "mobility": Size -diagonal mobility rate Numeric vector: Custom sizes node Single numeric: Fixed size nodes node_color Aesthetic mapping node color: "segment" (default): Color segment membership "mobility": Color mobility rate Character vector: Custom colors node Single color: Fixed color nodes node_alpha Numeric value (0-1) node transparency. Default 0.8. edge_width Aesthetic edge width: "weight" (default): Width proportional edge weight Numeric: Fixed width edges edge_color Color edges. Default "grey50". edge_alpha Numeric value (0-1) edge transparency. Default 0.6. show_labels Logical indicating whether display node labels. Default TRUE. label_size Numeric size node labels. Default 3. show_segments Logical indicating whether highlight segment boundaries. Default TRUE. segment_alpha Numeric value (0-1) segment boundary transparency. Default 0.3. color_palette Character string specifying color palette segments. Can RColorBrewer palette name. Default "Set3". theme_style Character string specifying plot theme: "void" (default): Clean background axes "minimal": Minimal theme subtle gridlines "classic": Traditional ggplot2 theme title Character string plot title. Default NULL (title). segment_naming Specifies name segments visualization. Can : Character string: "auto" (default), "concat", "pattern", "custom" -     passed segment.membership.enhanced automatic naming data.frame: Custom segment labels columns "name" (node names     mobility matrix) "segment_label" (desired custom labels). allows complete     control segment naming NULL: Uses default "auto" strategy data.frame provided, custom labels override automatically generated names. data.frame approach useful meaningful business names (e.g., "Upper Management" instead "Segment 1") multilingual applications. ... Additional arguments passed ggraph layout functions.

title: Modern Network Visualization for MONECA Results — plot_moneca_ggraph
text: ggplot2 object can customized displayed.

title: Modern Network Visualization for MONECA Results — plot_moneca_ggraph
text: function creates publication-quality network visualizations extensive customization options. automatically handles node positioning, edge rendering, segment highlighting. resulting plot can modified using standard ggplot2 syntax. interactive exploration, different layout algorithms may work better different network structures. Force-directed layouts ("fr") work well cases, "stress" layouts often produce cleaner results dense networks. Segment Naming: new data.frame approach segment_naming provides complete control segments labeled. particularly useful : Business applications meaningful names essential (e.g., "Senior Management" vs "Segment 1") Multilingual visualizations labels need translation Presentations consistent, professional terminology required Partial customization specific segments need custom names

title: Modern Network Visualization for MONECA Results — plot_moneca_ggraph
code: # Generate synthetic data and run MONECA mobility_data <- generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 6, seed = 123) seg <- moneca(mobility_data, segment.levels = 3) #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |==========                                                            |  14% #> 25% ready! #>    |                                                                               |====================                                                  |  29%   |                                                                               |==============================                                        |  43% #> 50% ready! #>    |                                                                               |========================================                              |  57%   |                                                                               |==================================================                    |  71% #> 75% ready! #>    |                                                                               |============================================================          |  86%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% #> 100% ready! #>   # Basic network plot plot_moneca_ggraph(seg)   # Customized plot with different aesthetics plot_moneca_ggraph(seg,   layout = "stress",   node_color = "mobility",   edge_width = "weight",   color_palette = "Spectral",   title = "Social Mobility Network",   show_segments = FALSE )   # Plot with custom node sizes and colors custom_plot <- plot_moneca_ggraph(seg,   node_size = c(8, 6, 10, 4, 7, 5),   node_color = "red",   edge_color = "darkblue",   theme_style = "minimal" )  # Further customize with ggplot2 custom_plot +    ggplot2::labs(subtitle = "Custom subtitle") +   ggplot2::theme(plot.title = ggplot2::element_text(size = 16))   # Using custom segment labels with data.frame (NEW FUNCTIONALITY) node_names <- rownames(mobility_data)[-nrow(mobility_data)]  # Remove "Total" row  # Example 1: Professional category labels professional_labels <- data.frame(   name = node_names,   segment_label = c("Senior Management", "Middle Management", "Professional Staff",                      "Technical Staff", "Administrative", "Support Staff")[1:length(node_names)],   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  professional_plot <- plot_moneca_ggraph(seg,   segment_naming = professional_labels,   title = "Professional Hierarchy Analysis" )  # Example 2: Partial custom labeling (mix of custom and auto-generated) partial_labels <- data.frame(   name = node_names[1:2],  # Only label first two categories   segment_label = c("Executive Level", "Management Level"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  partial_plot <- plot_moneca_ggraph(seg,   segment_naming = partial_labels,   title = "Mixed Labeling Approach" )  # Example 3: Comparing naming strategies auto_plot <- plot_moneca_ggraph(seg, segment_naming = "auto",                                 title = "Automatic Naming") concat_plot <- plot_moneca_ggraph(seg, segment_naming = "concat",                                   title = "Concatenated Names")
